Readme.Unnamed: 2: Metadata dictionary for the highest level of data organization.

Readme.Unnamed: 3: Collection metadata must be submitted prior to dataset metadata being submitted. Collection and file level metadata is inherited up and down and shown at a virtual dataset level.

Readme.Unnamed: 2: Metadata dictionary for the files that will be submitted.

Core Collection-V 1.0.Definition: A short name for high level data collection
An overview or summary detailing the content, nature, and purpose of the entire data collection.
The name of the lead individual who oversees and is the primary point of contact for the entire data collection process
The email address of the Principal Contact
The person responsible for curating, updating, and/or maintaining this data collection
The email address of the person responsible for this data collection

Core Collection-V 1.0.Permissible Value Definition:
Interlab: An interlab study involves multiple laboratories performing the same experiments independently to answer a specific question. The purpose is to assess the reproducibility and reliability of results across different settings and to identify any variations in protocols or measurements.
Characterization: A characterization study is focused on the detailed examination and description of a particular aspect of the study subject, which can be a biological process, chemical substance, or physical material. The goal is to gain in-depth understanding and to describe the properties or characteristics that define the subject of study.
Optimization: An optimization study signifies that the purpose of the research is to determine the most effective conditions, protocols, or parameters for a particular procedure or experiment. The objective is to refine the process to achieve the best possible performance or outcomes. (I don't think of characterization and optimization as separate experiment types)
Calibration/Instrument maintenance: A procedure performed to qualify the performance of an instrument in support of multiple experiments
Core Collection-V 1.0.Definition: The category of study based on the nature and objectives of the research.

Core File V 1.0.Definition: The name of the file
The person responsible for this data collection
The email address of the person responsible for this data collection

Core File V 1.0.Permissible Value Definition:
Proposed Permissilbe Value Definitions:

Raw: Data in its most original form as directly captured by measurement instruments or data collection tools. Raw data has not been processed or altered, ensuring it remains true to the initial observations.

Intermediate: Data that has undergone initial processing steps to prepare it for further analysis. This may include cleaning, normalization, error correction, or other preliminary transformations aimed at removing obvious artifacts or inconsistencies. Intermediate data is a transitional state that makes the data more suitable for detailed analysis or for deriving insights, yet it retains a close relationship to the raw data. This level of data may also include aggregated or summarized forms that simplify further analysis without reaching final conclusions or interpretations.

Derived: Data that has been extensively processed and transformed, often resulting in a format or structure that is significantly different from the original raw data. Derived data includes outcomes of analytical models, statistical analyses, interpretations, or any form of higher-level synthesis of the initial data. 

Not Applicable: This is where would be used for documentation, SOP, etc.
Core File V 1.0.Proposed Change: Propose: Add Not Applicable to permissible values for SOPs, documentation, etc.
Core File V 1.0.Definition: The state of the data. This can range from raw, intermediate data to derived datasets. It categorizes the stage of processing or transformation data has undergone from its initial collection to its current state. This field indicates the degree of modification, analysis, or synthesis applied to the original observations, facilitating an understanding of the data's readiness for use, its proximity to raw observations, and the level of interpretation or conclusion it represents.

Core File V 1.0.Permissible Values:
Study Design
Benchmark
Telemetry
Participant Data
Exploratory Data
Reference Material
Core File V 1.0.Permissible Value Definition:
Draft Permissible Value Definitions:

Study Design: Defines the plan for conducting scientific research, including hypotheses, variables, and experimental or observational methods. Includes SOPs, protocols, diagrams, etc. [If the name is "DataFileContext" then Study Design doesn't belong here. Instead we would use "Not Applicable" for anything that isn't a data file]
Benchmark Data: Establishes a standard for comparison, often used for performance assessment or calibration purposes.
Telemetry Data: Represents data automatically transmitted from remote or inaccessible sources to an IT system in a different location for monitoring and analysis.
Participant Data: Contains individual data points contributed by study participants, such as biological samples, survey responses, or clinical data.
Exploratory Data: Comprises initial findings and raw data used for hypothesis generation or pilot analysis. 
(I don't find participant vs exploratory useful, instead I would use a parallel to "Telemetry" (maybe called Research Data) with the definition "Represents data collected from measurement instruments in support of research projects")
Reference Material Data: Consists of authoritative data, sources and background documents that inform and support the research context collected from a reference material or standard reference material.
Core File V 1.0.Definition: Describe the broad category or type of data being captured

Core File V 1.0.Permissible Values:
NIST Documentation
SOP
Instrument Output
Results
Reference File
Protocol
Core File V 1.0.Permissible Value Definition:
Proposed Permissible Value Definitions:

Documentation: Includes all supporting narrative and descriptive information related to the data or study. (The permissible value says NIST Documentation, do we need a separate category for External Documentation?)
SOP (Standard Operating Procedure): Documents the established procedure or protocol to be followed in carrying out a given operation or in a given situation in collection of raw data or analysis.
Protocol: Documents the actual procedure or protocol to be followed in collection of raw data or analysis
Instrument Output: Captures raw or processed datasets generated by scientific instruments or computational analyses.
Results: Summarizes the findings, conclusions, or outputs of data analysis, often in the form of tables, graphs, or written reports.
Reference File: Serves as a normative or standard file, providing a benchmark or template for data comparison or verification.
Core File V 1.0.Definition: This field identifies the principal nature of the file content, providing immediate insight into the type of information the file contains and its relevance to the data collection.

Core File V 1.0.Permissible Values:
Nucleic acids
Proteins
Cells
Complex
Tissue
Non-biologic
Viral particle
Vesicle
Core File V 1.0.Permissible Value Definition:
Proposed Permissible Value Definitions:

Nucleic Acids: Biological molecules consisting of nucleotides essential for known forms of life. Includes DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) and RNA (ribonucleic acid), which carry genetic information critical for heredity, cellular functioning, and the synthesis of proteins. (others?)
Proteins: Complex molecules composed of amino acids that perform a vast array of functions within organisms, such as catalyzing metabolic reactions, replicating DNA, responding to stimuli, and transporting molecules from one location to another. Can include modified proteins such as glycoproteins
Cells: The basic building blocks of all living organisms, cells are the smallest units of life. (Something along the lines of: membrane bound particle containing nucleic acids, proteins, and/or chemicals. This definition might need to be pulled from ISO TC276 docs ) They can be procured from multicellular organisms (eukaryotic cells) or single-celled organisms (prokaryotic cells like bacteria).
Complex: A composition of two or more different types of materials that are not easily categorized into a single type. This includes mixed biological materials, environmental samples, synthetic-biological hybrids, or complex molecular structures.
Tissue: Groups of similar cells that work together to perform a specific function. Tissues are more complex structures, forming parts of organs in plants, animals, and humans.
Non-biologic: Materials that are not derived from living organisms and do not contain biological components. This category includes synthetic chemicals, plastics, metals, and other man-made materials used in experimental setups.
Viral Particle: Also known as a virion, a viral particle is the complete, infectious form of a virus outside a host cell. Viral particles consist of genetic material (DNA or RNA) enclosed in a protein coat and, in some cases, an outer lipid envelope.
Extracellular vesicle: ?
Not Applicable
Core File V 1.0.Definition: A classification indicating the specific type of biological or synthetic material utilized in the experiment.

Core File V 1.0.Permissible Value Definition: (We might not be ready to define this list of permissible values. We also might not want it in core file, depending on the set of use cases)
Core File V 1.0.Definition: The specific entity or property being measured, quantified, or evaluated in an experiment or observational study. It encompasses a wide range of quantitative and qualitative characteristics, including physical dimensions, chemical concentrations, biological markers, or environmental factors.

Core File V 1.0.Permissible Values:
RT-qPCR
ddPCR
Gel Electrophoresis
Plate Reader
Microscopy
Fluorescence Flow Cytometry
Impedance Flow Cytometry
DNA Sequencing 
RNA Sequencing
DNA Fragment Analysis
Modeling
Cell Culture
Transfection
Nucleic Acid Detection
Colony Forming Units
Not Applicable
Core File V 1.0.Permissible Value Definition:
RT-qPCR: Reverse Transcription Quantitative Polymerase Chain Reaction. A laboratory technique combining reverse transcription of RNA into DNA and amplification of specific DNA targets using polymerase chain reaction (PCR). It is used to measure the amount of a specific RNA, thus allowing detection and quantification of gene expression.

ddPCR: Droplet Digital PCR). A method of PCR that partitions a sample into thousands of droplets and performs DNA amplification in each individual droplet. ddPCR allows for highly precise, absolute quantification of nucleic acid target molecules with increased sensitivity and precision compared to traditional PCR techniques.

Gel Electrophoresis: A technique used to separate mixtures of DNA, RNA, or proteins according to molecular size. The molecules are separated forced through a gel matrix by an electric field, enabling separation and subsequent analysis.

Plate Reader: A laboratory instrument used to detect biological, chemical, or physical events of measure light absorption, fluorescence, or luminescence of samples in microtiter plates. It is commonly used for assays in cell biology, microbiology, and molecular biology that require measurements of .

Microscopy: A techniques for viewing structures that are too small to be seen with the naked eye. Types of microscopy can include light microscopy, fluorescence microscopy, and electron microscopy, among others.

Fluorescence Flow Cytometry: A technology that is used to analyze the physical and chemical characteristics of particles in a fluid as they passes through at least one laser. Cell Particle components can be are fluorescently labeled and then excited by the laser to emit light at varying wavelengths that will be captured by a set of filtered detectors.

Impedance Flow Cytometry: A technology  used to analyze the impedance of particles in a fluid as they passes through a channel or aperture, for example, a Coulter Counter. 

DNA Sequencing: The process of determining the precise order of nucleotides within a DNA molecule. It includes any method or technology that is used to determine the order of the four bases: adenine, guanine, cytosine, and thymine.

RNA Sequencing: A sequencing technique used to determine the quantity and sequences of RNA in a sample using next-generation sequencing (NGS) (I don't think this is right). This allows researchers to observe the continuously changing cellular transcriptome.

DNA Fragment Analysis: Techniques used to detect and measure specific DNA fragments; often used in genetics for analyzing gene mutations and polymorphisms, and in forensic analysis for DNA profiling.

Modeling - The use of mathematical formulas, computer simulations, or other abstract models to predict or simulate the behavior of systems from biological entities to drug interactions.

Cell Culture - A laboratory process by which cells are grown under controlled conditions, generally outside of their natural environment, typically to study biological processes, perform drug testing, or produce biological compounds.

Transfection - The process of deliberately introducing nucleic acids into cells. The term is used especially for non-viral methods in eukaryotic cells.

Nucleic Acid Detection - Techniques used to detect the presence of DNA or RNA in a sample. These techniques may involve the use of enzymatic reactions, fluorescent dyes, or hybridization probes to identify specific sequences.

Colony Forming Units (CFU) - A measure method used in microbiology to estimate the number of viable bacteria or fungal cell objects in a sample that are capable of proliferation on solid media. Each unit is assumed to arise from a single viable cell, and is used to estimate cell populations based on colony growth on solid media.

Not Applicable

Core File V 1.0.Permissible Values:
Quality Control
Data Visualization
Data Analysis
Core File V 1.0.Permissible Value Definition:
Quality Control: A tool or set of procedures implemented to ensure that a data set meets the required standards of quality. This may involve the identification and correction of errors or the exclusion of outlier data points.

Data Visualization: The graphical representation of data to communicate information clearly and effectively through statistical graphics, plots, information graphics, tables, or and charts. Data visualization tools help users to see analytics presented visually, so they can grasp difficult concepts or identify new patterns more easily. 

Data Analysis: A tool or processes and techniques used to compile, process, or and analyze data to discover useful information, inform conclusions, and support decision-making. Data analysis tools range from simple statistical techniques to complex computational algorithms, enabling users to manipulate data to extract actionable insights and trends.
Core File V 1.0.Definition: Types of applications included for in platform data analysis

Core File V 1.0.Definition: The DOI (Digital Object Identifier) - A unique alphanumeric string assigned to a dataset, providing a permanent link to its location on the internet. The DOI ensures consistent citation, accessibility, and discoverability of the dataset, even if its online location changes.
A stable web link or address that uses the Digital Object Identifier (DOI) to direct users to the specific online location or repository where the dataset can be accessed or downloaded
The specific date and time when the file was originally created or produced, indicating its point of origin in chronological terms
A unique alphanumeric string generated from the MD5 (Message-Digest Algorithm 5) hashing algorithm that represents the contents of a file.
Tags this file to appear highlighted in the File Level list in the LabCAS user interface.
Tags this file to appear at the top of the list of files in the File Level list in the LabCAS user interface.

Structure.Description: A collection is the highest-level structural element for organizing data in LabCAS. This is the Core Collection metadata.
Structure.Stewardship: Version 0.1 maintained by Heather Kincaid. Last updated 2023-09-14

Structure.Description: A dataset contains a set of data files but can also contain other datasets, forming a nested composition. This is the Core Dataset metadata.
Structure.Stewardship: Version 0.1 maintained by Heather Kincaid. Last updated 2023-09-14

Structure.Description: The files are the actual computer files of data that comprise the scientific instrument output of observations, experiments, and so forth. This is the Core File metadata. Attributes that are not specified for a core file inherit their values from their parent datasets or parent collection.
Structure.Stewardship: Version 0.1 maintained by Heather Kincaid. Last updated 2023-09-14

Structure.Description: NIST Flow Cytometry Standards Consortium file metadata extensions. This metadata is included in addition to the Core metadata for the Flow Cytometry ILS data.
Structure.Stewardship: Version 0.1 maintained by John Elliott. Last updated 2023-09-14
